group_1.narration: Always and to the very end,@Alina had been fickle and elusive.@Though I'd wanted to speak with her the most,@I never received that opportunity.
Then there is Folklore of Zero, all but disbanded.@It is simply a group of four close friends now.@They each have taken refuge in@a faction of their choosing.
One day, when I went to Nayuta's@house to discuss my book,@I found Miss Rabi there doing housework as usual,@and the Professor drinking coffee with them.

group_1.textLeft: So you finished your coverage of the Kamihama@Magical Girls and our final battle?

group_1.textRight: I'm not nearly done. The most I've done is arrange@the material...
It's not like a novel or an essay, so it's difficult@to settle on the right way to convey it.

group_1.textLeft: So that's what's brought you here today.@You want to figure out how to organize it.
How fortunate that I invited Papa here today as@well!
He'd forgotten about Iroha,@so he's here for a reminder.
Must she disturb the neighbors at this hour?

group_1.narration: *Slam!*
―Mikage―@Didja finish the book,@Kagomechin?!
―Mikage―@Oh, hey Nayutan's dad,@you're here too!
―Mikage―@So when are you gonna spread@the truth about Magical Girls?!
―Nayuta―@If you're letting yourself inside anyway,@there's no need to shout.
―Nayuta―@Our key is evidently no longer working,@after all!
―Rabi―@My apologies. I must have forgotten to@lock the door after retrieving the newspaper.
―Nayuta―@Oh my,@that's unusual for you.
―Rabi―@Yes, it seems some of your faults@have passed onto me, Mistress...
―Nayuta―@Oh, I see...@Wait, excuse me?! What did you just say...?!
―Mikage―@So when's it gonna go public?!
―Tasuke―@It's not ready yet.@It'll need many rounds of revision, for starters...
―Kagome―@I need to review what I've written@and decide how to arrange the narrative...
―Tasuke―@And even once the book is ready,@we can't just explain everything about Magical Girls.
―Tasuke―@We need to learn from our experiences@and push things little by little.
―Kagome―@Will that be related to@how I put my book together?
―Tasuke―@Indeed.
―Tasuke―@People struggle against having our preconceptions@overturned and adopting new ideas.
―Tasuke―@It makes it difficult for us to be flexible.
―Tasuke―@So just like how various disciplines have introductory books, I think@it would be better for us to approach this in a step-by-step process.
―Rabi―@We've only just begun, after all.@We shouldn't rush ourselves.
―Rabi―@It seems that the information flow you came up with,@in case we managed to avoid resignation, will be useful now.
―Tasuke―@Right, just like the spread of folklore itself.
―Tasuke―@It'll probably take another ten or twenty years@for the story of Magical Girls to be delivered.
